name: Aciclovir (Zovirax)
description: Aciclovir is an antiviral medication used to treat infections caused by certain types of viruses. It is most commonly used to treat herpes simplex virus infections, including genital herpes, cold sores, and shingles.
dosage:
Adults: 200 mg five times a day for 5 days for herpes simplex.

Shingles: 800 mg five times a day for 7 days.

Children dosage depends on weight and indication. Always follow doctor’s advice.
sideEffects:
Common: nausea, diarrhea, headache.

Rare: confusion, hallucinations, skin rash or itching.
importantInfo: Start treatment as soon as symptoms appear. Stay well hydrated. Inform your doctor if you have kidney issues or are pregnant. Do not skip doses.

name: Acrivastine
description: Acrivastine is an antihistamine used to relieve symptoms of allergies such as hay fever, urticaria (hives), and insect bites. It works by blocking histamine, a substance in the body that causes allergic symptoms.
dosage:
Adults and children over 12: One 8 mg capsule up to three times daily.

Not recommended for children under 12 years.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dry mouth, dizziness, and nausea are common.

Serious reactions are rare but may include allergic rash or difficulty breathing.
importantInfo: Avoid alcohol while taking this medicine. May cause drowsiness—do not drive or operate machinery if affected. Consult a doctor if symptoms persist.

name: Adalimumab
description: Adalimumab is a biologic medication used to treat autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease, psoriasis, and ulcerative colitis by blocking TNF-alpha.
dosage:
Given as a subcutaneous injection. Dosage varies by condition: commonly 40 mg every other week.

Exact regimen must be prescribed by a healthcare provider.
sideEffects:
Common: injection site reactions, upper respiratory infections.

Serious: risk of serious infections, liver problems, allergic reactions, blood disorders.
importantInfo: Regular monitoring with blood tests may be required. Avoid live vaccines during treatment. Notify your doctor of any signs of infection or if you're planning surgery.

name: Alendronic acid
description: Alendronic acid is used to treat and prevent osteoporosis by slowing down the process of bone loss. It helps to maintain strong bones and reduce the risk of fractures.
dosage:
Typical dose is 70 mg once weekly or 10 mg once daily.

Must be taken on an empty stomach with water, at least 30 minutes before food or drink.

Remain upright for 30 minutes after taking.
sideEffects:
Common: stomach pain, heartburn, indigestion, constipation or diarrhea.

Rare: jaw bone problems (osteonecrosis), unusual thigh bone fractures.
importantInfo: Do not lie down after taking. Take with a full glass of plain water only. Notify your dentist before procedures. Ensure sufficient calcium and vitamin D intake.

name: Allopurinol
description: Allopurinol is used to treat gout and kidney stones by reducing the production of uric acid in the body. It is also prescribed to prevent increased uric acid levels during cancer treatment.
dosage:
Initial dose: 100 mg daily, increased gradually based on uric acid levels.

Typical maintenance: 200–600 mg daily in divided doses.

Ensure adequate fluid intake while using.
sideEffects:
Common: skin rash, nausea, diarrhea.

Rare but serious: hypersensitivity syndrome, liver abnormalities, bone marrow suppression.
importantInfo: Take after meals to reduce stomach upset. Stop immediately and seek help if rash develops. Monitor uric acid levels regularly. Dose adjustments may be needed in kidney impairment.

name: Alogliptin
description: Alogliptin is an oral medication used to treat type 2 diabetes. It works by increasing insulin release and lowering glucagon levels in the blood, especially after meals.
dosage:
Standard dose: 25 mg once daily, with or without food.

Lower doses may be recommended for patients with kidney problems.
sideEffects:
Common: headache, upper respiratory tract infection, nausea.

Rare: pancreatitis, joint pain, allergic reactions.
importantInfo: Not for type 1 diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis. Regular blood sugar monitoring is advised. Inform your doctor of any severe stomach pain or rash.

name: Amitriptyline
description: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant used for depression, nerve pain, and sometimes migraine prevention. It alters chemical signals in the brain to improve mood and reduce pain.
dosage:
For depression: 50–100 mg daily, adjusted based on response.

For nerve pain or migraine: 10–75 mg at night.

Start at low dose and titrate slowly.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dry mouth, weight gain, constipation.

May cause dizziness, blurred vision, or trouble urinating.
importantInfo: Avoid alcohol and driving until effects are known. Do not stop suddenly without medical advice. Can interact with other antidepressants and medications.

name: Amlodipine
description: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat high blood pressure and angina. It works by relaxing blood vessels, allowing blood to flow more easily and reducing heart workload.
dosage:
Initial dose: 5 mg once daily.

May be increased to 10 mg daily depending on response and tolerance.
sideEffects:
Common: swelling of ankles, headache, flushing, dizziness.

Less common: palpitations, fatigue, nausea.
importantInfo: Take at the same time each day. May take several weeks to see full effect. Do not stop abruptly without consulting your doctor.

name: Amoxicillin
description: Amoxicillin is a penicillin-type antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including ear infections, throat infections, urinary tract infections, and pneumonia.
dosage:
Typical adult dose: 250–500 mg every 8 hours, or 500–875 mg every 12 hours depending on severity.

Children: dosage based on weight and infection type.
sideEffects:
Common: nausea, diarrhea, skin rash.

Rare: allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis or Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
importantInfo:
Complete the full course even if symptoms improve early.

Notify your doctor if you develop a rash or signs of allergy.

Can affect oral contraceptive effectiveness.

name: Anastrozole
description: Anastrozole is used to treat breast cancer in postmenopausal women. It works by lowering estrogen levels, which can help shrink hormone receptor-positive tumors.
dosage:
1 mg once daily, taken at the same time each day.

Treatment duration varies based on cancer type and patient response.
sideEffects:
Common: hot flushes, joint pain, weakness.

May also cause bone thinning, mood changes, or nausea.
importantInfo:
Regular bone density monitoring may be required.

Tell your doctor if you have osteoporosis or liver issues.

Not for use in premenopausal women or during pregnancy.

name: Antidepressants
brand: Includes SSRIs (e.g., sertraline), SNRIs (e.g., venlafaxine), TCAs (e.g., amitriptyline), MAOIs, and atypical agents.
description: Antidepressants are a class of medications used to treat depression, anxiety disorders, PTSD, and other mental health conditions. They work by altering brain chemicals like serotonin and norepinephrine.
dosage:
Dosage varies greatly depending on the specific drug and individual condition.

Typically started at a low dose and adjusted slowly.
sideEffects:
Common: nausea, dry mouth, drowsiness, insomnia, sexual dysfunction.

Some may cause weight gain or increased anxiety at the start.
importantInfo:
Do not stop abruptly—may lead to withdrawal symptoms.

It may take 2–6 weeks to feel full effect.

Monitor for worsening mood or suicidal thoughts, especially early in treatment.

name: Apixaban
description: Apixaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) used to prevent and treat blood clots, including in conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism, and atrial fibrillation.
dosage:
Typical dose: 5 mg twice daily.

May be reduced to 2.5 mg twice daily in elderly or those with kidney impairment.
sideEffects:
Common: bleeding, bruising, nausea.

Rare: allergic reactions, liver enzyme changes.
importantInfo:
Do not stop without medical advice.

Avoid NSAIDs and other blood thinners unless instructed.

No routine blood monitoring required, but regular review is important.

name: Aripiprazole
description: Aripiprazole is an antipsychotic medication used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and as an adjunct for major depressive disorder. It works by balancing dopamine and serotonin in the brain.
dosage:
Typical adult dose: 10–15 mg once daily, adjustable up to 30 mg based on response.

Lower doses may be used for depression augmentation.
sideEffects:
Common: insomnia, restlessness, nausea, anxiety.

Rare: movement disorders, elevated blood sugar, suicidal thoughts.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol and monitor for behavior changes.

May impair judgment or coordination.

Tapering may be required when stopping.

name: Aspirin
description: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory and antiplatelet drug used for pain relief, fever, and heart attack/stroke prevention. It inhibits prostaglandins and platelet aggregation.
dosage:
For pain: 300–600 mg every 4–6 hours as needed.

For cardiovascular protection: 75–150 mg once daily.
sideEffects:
Common: stomach upset, heartburn, mild bleeding.

Rare: ulcers, allergic reactions, bleeding disorders.
importantInfo:
Take with food or milk to reduce stomach irritation.

Avoid with other NSAIDs or blood thinners unless advised.

Not suitable for children under 16 (Reye’s syndrome risk).

name: Atenolol
description: Atenolol is a beta-blocker used to treat high blood pressure, angina, and arrhythmias. It reduces heart rate and cardiac output, easing strain on the heart.
dosage:
Typical dose: 25–100 mg once daily.

Dose may be split or adjusted based on blood pressure response.
sideEffects:
Common: fatigue, cold extremities, dizziness.

May cause slow heart rate, sleep disturbances, or sexual dysfunction.
importantInfo:
Do not stop abruptly—may worsen heart conditions.

Use with caution in asthma, diabetes, or circulation problems.

Monitor heart rate and blood pressure regularly.

name: Atorvastatin
description: Atorvastatin is a statin used to lower cholesterol and reduce cardiovascular risk. It inhibits HMG-CoA reductase, decreasing LDL cholesterol production in the liver.
dosage:
Initial dose: 10–20 mg once daily.

Maximum dose: 80 mg daily, adjusted based on cholesterol targets.
sideEffects:
Common: muscle aches, headache, digestive issues.

Rare: liver enzyme elevation, muscle breakdown (rhabdomyolysis).
importantInfo:
Avoid grapefruit juice.

Liver function should be monitored during treatment.

Report any unexplained muscle pain or weakness.

name: Azathioprine
brand: Imuran, Azapress, Azamun, Imurel, Azathioprine Sandoz.
description: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant used in autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease, and after organ transplants. It works by reducing immune system activity.
dosage:
Typically 1–3 mg/kg per day depending on condition and body weight.

Dosage is often adjusted based on white blood cell counts and liver function.
sideEffects:
Common: nausea, loss of appetite, increased infection risk.

Serious: liver damage, bone marrow suppression, pancreatitis.
importantInfo:
Requires regular blood tests to monitor liver function and blood cell counts.

Avoid live vaccines during treatment.

Inform your doctor about TPMT deficiency if known.

name: Azithromycin
description: Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic used to treat respiratory infections, skin infections, sexually transmitted infections, and ear infections.
dosage:
Typical adult dose: 500 mg on day 1, then 250 mg daily for 4 days.

STIs: single 1 g dose.

Pediatric dosing based on weight.
sideEffects:
Common: nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain.

Less common: liver enzyme elevation, QT prolongation, allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Take at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals if using tablets.

May interact with antacids or heart rhythm medications.

Complete the full course even if symptoms improve.

name: Baclofen
description: Baclofen is a muscle relaxant used to treat spasticity from conditions like multiple sclerosis or spinal cord injuries. It works by suppressing nerve signals in the spinal cord.
dosage:
Initial dose: 5 mg three times daily, increased gradually up to 80 mg/day if needed.

Dose must be adjusted slowly to avoid side effects.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dizziness, weakness, fatigue.

In high doses: confusion, low blood pressure, breathing issues.
importantInfo:
Do not stop suddenly—may cause withdrawal.

Caution with alcohol or other CNS depressants.

Use with care in elderly or those with kidney impairment.

name: Beclometasone
brand: Qvar, Clenil Modulite, Beconase, Becotide, Inhace.
description: Beclometasone is a corticosteroid used to treat asthma, allergic rhinitis, and other inflammatory conditions. It reduces swelling and irritation in the airways or nasal passages.
dosage:
Inhaler: 100–400 mcg twice daily depending on severity.

Nasal spray: 100–200 mcg per nostril daily for allergies.
sideEffects:
Hoarseness, sore throat, cough, oral thrush.

Long-term high doses may suppress adrenal function.
importantInfo:
Rinse mouth after inhaler use to prevent thrush.

Do not use for sudden asthma attacks—use a reliever inhaler.

Follow tapering instructions if discontinuing high doses.

name: Bendroflumethiazide
description: Bendroflumethiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to treat high blood pressure and fluid retention. It helps reduce excess fluid and salt by increasing urine output.
dosage:
For hypertension: 2.5 mg once daily.

For edema: 5–10 mg once daily, adjusted as needed.
sideEffects:
Dizziness, low potassium, dehydration, muscle cramps.

May increase blood sugar or uric acid levels.
importantInfo:
Monitor electrolytes and kidney function.

May increase sun sensitivity—use sunscreen.

Take in the morning to avoid nighttime urination.

name: Benzoyl peroxide
description: Benzoyl peroxide is a topical antibacterial used to treat acne. It works by killing bacteria on the skin and helping to unclog pores.
dosage:
Apply a thin layer once or twice daily to affected areas after cleansing.

Start with lower strengths to minimize irritation.
sideEffects:
Dryness, redness, peeling, stinging.

May bleach hair or fabrics it comes into contact with.
importantInfo:
Avoid contact with eyes, mouth, and mucous membranes.

Use sunscreen—skin may be more sensitive to sun.

Allow 4–6 weeks to see full benefit.

name: Benzydamine
brand: Difflam, Tantum Verde, Benzydox, Benzoral, Tantum.
description: Benzydamine is a local anti-inflammatory and analgesic used for mouth and throat pain, such as sore throat, mouth ulcers, or post-dental procedures.
dosage:
Mouthwash: rinse 15 ml every 1.5–3 hours, up to 8 times daily.

Spray: 4–8 puffs every 1.5–3 hours, as needed.
sideEffects:
Numbness, tingling, stinging.

Rarely: allergic reactions or mouth irritation.
importantInfo:
Do not swallow mouthwash.

Avoid eating or drinking immediately after use.

Stop use if signs of sensitivity or allergy occur.

name: Betahistine
description: Betahistine is used to treat vertigo and balance disorders such as Ménière’s disease. It works by improving blood flow in the inner ear.
dosage:
Usual dose: 16 mg three times daily or 24 mg twice daily.

May take a few weeks for full effect.
sideEffects:
Nausea, headache, indigestion.

Occasionally: rash or allergic reaction.
importantInfo:
Take with food to reduce stomach upset.

Continue taking regularly for best results.

Inform your doctor if symptoms persist or worsen.

name: Betamethasone
description: Betamethasone is a potent corticosteroid used to treat inflammatory skin conditions such as eczema, psoriasis, and dermatitis. It reduces redness, itching, and swelling.
dosage:
Apply a thin layer once or twice daily to affected area.

Do not use on large areas or under dressings unless advised.
sideEffects:
Skin thinning, stretch marks, burning or stinging.

Prolonged use may lead to hormonal side effects or infection.
importantInfo:
Use sparingly and only for short periods unless instructed.

Avoid use on face or broken skin unless prescribed.

Do not suddenly stop long-term use—taper as advised.

name: Bimatoprost (Lumigan)
description: Bimatoprost is an eye drop used to lower intraocular pressure in conditions like glaucoma or ocular hypertension. It increases fluid drainage from the eye.
dosage:
One drop into the affected eye(s) once daily, typically in the evening.

Do not exceed recommended frequency.
sideEffects:
Redness, eyelash growth, darkening of the eyelid or iris.

Possible eye irritation or dryness.
importantInfo:
Remove contact lenses before use and wait 15 minutes before reinserting.

Avoid touching dropper tip to any surface.

Tell your doctor if you have eye infections or swelling.

name: Bisacodyl
brand: Dulcolax, Fleet Laxative, Muxol, Alophen, Carter's Little Pills.
description: Bisacodyl is a stimulant laxative used to relieve occasional constipation. It works by stimulating bowel movements through irritation of the intestinal lining.
dosage:
Oral: 5–10 mg once daily as needed.

Suppository: 10 mg rectally, typically effective within 15–60 minutes.
sideEffects:
Abdominal cramps, diarrhea, nausea.

Prolonged use may cause electrolyte imbalance or dependency.
importantInfo:
Take oral tablets with water and do not crush or chew.

Do not use for more than 5 consecutive days.

Stay hydrated and maintain dietary fiber intake.

name: Bisoprolol
brand: Concor, Zebeta, Bisocard, Biselect, Bisoprolol Mylan.
description: Bisoprolol is a beta-blocker used to manage high blood pressure, heart failure, and angina. It slows the heart rate and reduces strain on the heart.
dosage:
Initial dose: 5 mg once daily.

May be adjusted between 2.5–20 mg daily based on response.
sideEffects:
Fatigue, cold hands/feet, slow heartbeat.

Possible dizziness, sleep issues, or shortness of breath.
importantInfo:
Do not stop suddenly—risk of heart complications.

Caution in asthma, diabetes, or heart block.

Take at the same time each day, with or without food.

name: Brinzolamide
brand: Azopt, Simbrinza (with brimonidine), Brinzoft, Bryzoft, Optri.
description: Brinzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in the form of eye drops to reduce intraocular pressure in glaucoma and ocular hypertension.
dosage:
One drop in the affected eye(s) twice daily.

If used with other eye drops, space doses at least 10 minutes apart.
sideEffects:
Blurred vision, bitter taste, dry eyes.

Less commonly: eye discomfort, headache, or allergic reaction.
importantInfo:
Shake well before use.

Do not touch the dropper tip to your eye or any surface.

Contact lenses should be removed before application and reinserted after 15 minutes.

name: Budesonide
description: Budesonide is a corticosteroid used for asthma, Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, and allergic rhinitis. It reduces inflammation in the airways or gastrointestinal tract.
dosage:
Inhaler: 200–800 mcg daily in divided doses.

For IBD: 9 mg once daily in the morning, typically for up to 8 weeks.
sideEffects:
Hoarseness, oral thrush, headache.

Rare: adrenal suppression, slowed growth in children.
importantInfo:
Rinse mouth after inhalation to prevent thrush.

Do not use inhaler as a rescue medication.

Taper slowly if stopping long-term use.

name: Bumetanide
description: Bumetanide is a loop diuretic used to treat fluid overload (edema) in conditions like heart failure, liver disease, or kidney disease by increasing urine output.
dosage:
Typical dose: 0.5–2 mg once daily.

May be given in divided doses depending on response.
sideEffects:
Frequent urination, low potassium, dizziness.

May cause dehydration or changes in blood pressure.
importantInfo:
Monitor electrolytes and kidney function.

Take in the morning to avoid nighttime urination.

Stand up slowly to prevent dizziness.

name: Buprenorphine
brand: Subutex, Suboxone (with naloxone), Butrans, Temgesic, Norspan.
description: Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used for pain relief and opioid dependence. It helps reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings.
dosage:
For opioid dependence: 2–8 mg sublingually daily, adjusted as needed.

For pain: transdermal patches changed weekly or sublingual tablets as directed.
sideEffects:
Constipation, dizziness, drowsiness, headache.

Serious: respiratory depression, dependence, liver enzyme changes.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol and other sedatives.

Do not cut patches or stop suddenly.

Must be prescribed and monitored under medical supervision.

name: Buscopan (hyoscine butylbromide)
brand: Buscopan, Scopolan, Hyospasmol, Colofac IBS, Spasmopriv.
description: Buscopan is an antispasmodic used to relieve abdominal cramps, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), and menstrual pain. It works by relaxing smooth muscles in the gut.
dosage:
Usual adult dose: 10 mg three times a day.

Can be increased to 20 mg four times daily for severe symptoms.
sideEffects:
Dry mouth, dizziness, blurred vision.

Rare: urinary retention, allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Do not use if you have glaucoma or myasthenia gravis.

Avoid alcohol if it increases drowsiness.

Tell your doctor if symptoms persist or worsen.

name: Calcipotriol
description: Calcipotriol is a vitamin D analogue used topically to treat plaque psoriasis. It slows down the growth of skin cells and reduces scaling.
dosage:
Apply a thin layer to affected areas once or twice daily.

Do not use more than 100 g per week in adults.
sideEffects:
Skin irritation, redness, itching.

Rare: hypercalcemia with excessive use.
importantInfo:
Avoid use on face, flexures, or broken skin.

Do not use with calcium supplements unless advised.

Wash hands after application unless treating hands.

name: Candesartan
description: Candesartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure. It helps relax blood vessels and lower blood pressure.
dosage:
Hypertension: 8–32 mg once daily.

Heart failure: starting dose 4 mg daily, titrated up based on response.
sideEffects:
Dizziness, headache, tiredness.

Rare: low blood pressure, kidney problems, high potassium.
importantInfo:
Monitor kidney function and potassium levels.

Not recommended during pregnancy.

Take at the same time each day, with or without food.

name: Carbamazepine
description: Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant used to treat epilepsy, trigeminal neuralgia, and bipolar disorder. It stabilizes nerve activity in the brain.
dosage:
Initial dose: 100–200 mg once or twice daily.

Maintenance: 800–1,200 mg daily in divided doses, based on condition and response.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dizziness, nausea, unsteadiness.

Serious: liver issues, blood disorders, severe skin reactions.
importantInfo:
Requires regular blood and liver tests.

May reduce effectiveness of oral contraceptives.

Do not stop suddenly—risk of seizures.

name: Carbimazole
description: Carbimazole is used to treat hyperthyroidism by reducing the production of thyroid hormones. It is commonly prescribed in Graves' disease.
dosage:
Initial dose: 15–40 mg daily, usually divided into 2–3 doses.

Maintenance: 5–15 mg once daily depending on thyroid function tests.
sideEffects:
Rash, joint pain, nausea.

Rare but serious: agranulocytosis, liver dysfunction.
importantInfo:
Report sore throat, fever, or mouth ulcers immediately — may indicate low white blood cells.

Regular blood tests are required.

Not recommended during pregnancy unless under specialist care.

name: Carbocisteine
description: Carbocisteine is a mucolytic agent used to thin and loosen mucus in the airways, making it easier to cough up. It is used in chronic respiratory conditions like COPD.
dosage:
Adults: 750 mg three times daily, reduced to 500 mg three times once improvement is seen.

Children’s doses depend on age and weight.
sideEffects:
Nausea, diarrhea, stomach discomfort.

Rare: skin rash or allergic reaction.
importantInfo:
Take with plenty of fluid.

Avoid in active peptic ulcers.

May take a few days to show full benefit.

name: Carmellose
brand: Celluvisc, Refresh Tears, Optive, Viscotears, Lacri-Lube.
description: Carmellose (carboxymethylcellulose) is an eye lubricant used to relieve dry eyes and irritation caused by wind, sun, computer use, or certain medications.
dosage:
Instill 1 or 2 drops in the affected eye(s) as needed.

Can be used several times a day depending on symptoms.
sideEffects:
Temporary blurred vision, eye discomfort, stinging.

Rare: allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Do not touch dropper tip to any surface.

Remove contact lenses before use.

Wait 10–15 minutes before using other eye medications.

name: Carvedilol
description: Carvedilol is a beta-blocker used to treat high blood pressure, heart failure, and angina. It reduces heart rate and improves heart function.
dosage:
Hypertension: 12.5–50 mg daily in divided doses.

Heart failure: start with 3.125 mg twice daily, gradually increased as tolerated.
sideEffects:
Fatigue, dizziness, slow heart rate, low blood pressure.

May cause weight gain or worsen breathing in some patients.
importantInfo:
Take with food to reduce dizziness.

Do not stop suddenly—may worsen heart conditions.

Monitor blood pressure and pulse regularly.

name: Cefalexin
description: Cefalexin is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections including skin infections, respiratory tract infections, and urinary tract infections.
dosage:
Adults: 250–500 mg every 6 hours, or 500 mg every 12 hours.

Children: 25–50 mg/kg per day in divided doses.
sideEffects:
Nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain.

Rare: allergic reactions, including rash or anaphylaxis.
importantInfo:
Complete the full course even if symptoms improve.

Take with or without food.

Inform your doctor if you are allergic to penicillin or cephalosporins.

name: Cetirizine
brand: Zyrtec, Benadryl Allergy One-a-day, Cetrine, Zirtek, Piriteze.
description: Cetirizine is a non-drowsy antihistamine used for hay fever, hives, insect bites, and other allergic reactions. It works by blocking histamine receptors.
dosage:
Adults and children over 12: 10 mg once daily.

Children 6–12: 5 mg twice daily.

Not recommended for children under 6 unless advised.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dry mouth, headache.

Rare: stomach upset, rash, allergic reaction.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol if it increases drowsiness.

Can be taken with or without food.

Do not exceed the recommended dose.

name: Chloramphenicol
brand: Chloromycetin, Optrex Infected Eye, Cpl Eye Drops, Golden Eye, Minims.
description: Chloramphenicol is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used in eye drops and ointments to treat bacterial conjunctivitis and other eye infections.
dosage:
Eye drops: 1 drop every 2 hours during waking hours for the first 2 days, then 4 times daily.

Ointment: apply 3–4 times daily or at night.
sideEffects:
Temporary stinging or burning.

Rare: blurred vision, allergic reactions, bone marrow suppression with prolonged use.
importantInfo:
Do not wear contact lenses during treatment.

Discard eye drops 5 days after opening.

Use exactly as directed to avoid resistance.

name: Chlorhexidine
description: Chlorhexidine is an antiseptic used in mouthwash, skin cleanser, and wound care products. It kills bacteria and is commonly used to treat or prevent gum disease.
dosage:
Mouthwash: rinse with 10–15 ml twice daily.

Topical: apply a small amount to the affected area as directed.
sideEffects:
Altered taste, mouth irritation, staining of teeth or tongue.

Rare: allergic reaction or swelling.
importantInfo:
Avoid eating or drinking immediately after use.

Prolonged use can stain teeth—use as directed.

Do not swallow mouthwash.

name: Chlorphenamine (Piriton)
description: Chlorphenamine is a sedating antihistamine used for allergic reactions, hay fever, hives, and insect bites. It works by blocking histamine to reduce symptoms like itching and swelling.
dosage:
Adults: 4 mg every 4–6 hours, max 24 mg/day.

Children: dosage varies by age — always follow packaging or doctor’s advice.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dry mouth, dizziness, blurred vision.

May cause constipation or difficulty urinating.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol and driving.

Do not use with other sedating antihistamines.

Use with caution in asthma, glaucoma, or prostate problems.

name: Cinnarizine
description: Cinnarizine is an antihistamine used to treat nausea, vomiting, vertigo, and motion sickness. It also improves blood flow in conditions like Ménière’s disease.
dosage:
Motion sickness: 30 mg two hours before travel, then 15 mg every 8 hours.

Vertigo: 30 mg three times daily.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dry mouth, weight gain.

Occasionally: stomach upset or rash.
importantInfo:
Take with or after food to reduce nausea.

May cause drowsiness — avoid alcohol and driving.

Prolonged use should be supervised by a doctor.

name: Ciprofloxacin
description: Ciprofloxacin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used for urinary tract infections, respiratory infections, and gastrointestinal infections. It is also used in eye/ear drops.
dosage:
Typical adult oral dose: 250–750 mg twice daily.

Duration depends on infection type and severity.
sideEffects:
Nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, rash.

Rare: tendon damage, seizures, mood changes.
importantInfo:
Avoid taking with dairy or calcium supplements.

Stay well hydrated and avoid excess sun.

Do not take with NSAIDs unless advised.

name: Citalopram
description: Citalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used to treat depression and anxiety disorders by increasing serotonin levels in the brain.
dosage:
Starting dose: 20 mg once daily.

May be increased to a maximum of 40 mg daily based on response.
sideEffects:
Nausea, dry mouth, drowsiness, sexual dysfunction.

May initially increase anxiety or agitation.
importantInfo:
Do not stop abruptly — taper slowly under medical supervision.

Takes 2–4 weeks to see full benefit.

Avoid alcohol and monitor for mood changes early in treatment.

name: Clarithromycin
description: Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic used to treat respiratory infections, skin infections, and stomach ulcers caused by *H. pylori*. It works by stopping the growth of bacteria.
dosage:
Typical adult dose: 250–500 mg twice daily for 7–14 days.

Can be used with other medications for *H. pylori* eradication.
sideEffects:
Nausea, diarrhea, taste changes, headache.

Rare: liver enzyme changes, QT prolongation, allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Can interact with many medications — inform your doctor of all current prescriptions.

Take with or without food.

Complete the course even if symptoms improve.

name: Clobetasol
description: Clobetasol is a very potent corticosteroid used for severe inflammatory skin conditions such as psoriasis, eczema, or lichen planus. It reduces redness, itching, and swelling.
dosage:
Apply thinly once or twice daily to affected area.

Use for no more than 2–4 weeks unless directed.
sideEffects:
Skin thinning, irritation, burning sensation.

Prolonged use may lead to hormonal side effects or stretch marks.
importantInfo:
Do not use on face or broken skin unless advised.

Avoid occlusive dressings unless directed.

Wash hands after use unless treating them.

name: Clobetasone
description: Clobetasone is a moderate strength steroid used to treat eczema, dermatitis, and other inflammatory skin conditions. It helps to reduce itching and redness.
dosage:
Apply a thin layer once or twice daily.

Treatment should be limited to short periods and reviewed regularly.
sideEffects:
Mild burning or stinging, skin thinning with prolonged use.

Rare: allergic rash or folliculitis.
importantInfo:
Avoid long-term use, especially on delicate skin areas.

Do not use on face or genitals unless prescribed.

Wash hands after applying.

name: Clonazepam
description: Clonazepam is a benzodiazepine used to treat seizures, panic disorder, and sometimes movement disorders. It works by calming brain activity.
dosage:
Seizures: initial 0.5 mg three times daily, titrated up as needed.

Panic disorder: 0.25–2 mg daily depending on severity.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dizziness, coordination problems.

Risk of dependence, memory issues, or depression with long-term use.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol and do not drive until you know how it affects you.

Taper off slowly — stopping suddenly may cause withdrawal or seizures.

Use short term unless advised otherwise.

name: Clonidine
description: Clonidine is primarily used to treat high blood pressure, ADHD, and withdrawal symptoms. It works by decreasing nerve signals that tighten blood vessels, lowering blood pressure and calming the nervous system.
dosage:
Hypertension: 100–200 mcg twice daily.

ADHD (off-label): starting at 25 mcg at bedtime, titrated slowly.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dry mouth, constipation, low blood pressure.

Can cause rebound hypertension if stopped suddenly.
importantInfo:
Do not stop abruptly — always taper off under medical supervision.

Take at the same times each day.

Monitor blood pressure regularly during treatment.

name: Clopidogrel
description: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet medication used to prevent blood clots after a heart attack, stroke, or stent placement. It prevents platelets from clumping together.
dosage:
Typical dose: 75 mg once daily.

May be given with aspirin in dual antiplatelet therapy.
sideEffects:
Bleeding, bruising, diarrhea, rash.

Rare: low white blood cells or allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Avoid NSAIDs unless directed — increases bleeding risk.

Tell all healthcare providers you’re taking clopidogrel.

Do not stop without medical advice.

name: Clotrimazole
description: Clotrimazole is an antifungal medication used to treat infections such as athlete’s foot, thrush, and ringworm. It stops the growth of fungi by affecting their cell membrane.
dosage:
Apply to the affected area 2–3 times daily for at least 2 weeks.

For vaginal infections, insert 1 pessary daily for 3–6 days depending on strength.
sideEffects:
Redness, itching, burning at application site.

Rare: allergic reaction or blistering.
importantInfo:
Complete full course even if symptoms improve.

Avoid using tight clothing over treated areas.

Do not use tampons or douches during vaginal treatment.

name: Clotrimazole (Canesten)
description: This formulation of clotrimazole is specifically used for treating vaginal thrush and external fungal infections. It helps relieve itching, discharge, and discomfort caused by fungal overgrowth.
dosage:
Cream: apply externally 2–3 times daily.

Pessary: 500 mg once or 100 mg daily for 6 days intravaginally.
sideEffects:
Mild irritation, burning, or redness.

Rare: allergic reaction or swelling.
importantInfo:
Use at bedtime for vaginal pessaries for best absorption.

Avoid sexual intercourse during treatment.

See a doctor if symptoms persist after treatment.

name: Co-amoxiclav
description: Co-amoxiclav is a combination antibiotic of amoxicillin and clavulanic acid. It is used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections by preventing bacterial resistance to amoxicillin.
dosage:
Adults: 500/125 mg every 8 hours, or 875/125 mg twice daily.

Children: dose based on weight, typically 20–40 mg/kg/day in divided doses.
sideEffects:
Diarrhea, nausea, skin rash.

Rare: liver enzyme elevation, jaundice, allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Take with food to reduce stomach upset.

Complete the full course as prescribed.

Inform your doctor of any penicillin allergies.

name: Co-beneldopa
description: Co-beneldopa is used to treat Parkinson’s disease. It combines levodopa (which converts to dopamine in the brain) with benserazide to enhance its effect and reduce side effects.
dosage:
Dose is individualized. Often starts with 62.5 mg 3–4 times daily, gradually increased.

Modified-release forms are also available.
sideEffects:
Nausea, dizziness, involuntary movements (dyskinesia).

May cause confusion or vivid dreams in some patients.
importantInfo:
Take at consistent times each day.

Avoid high-protein meals around dosing.

Do not stop suddenly — risk of serious symptoms.

name: Co-careldopa
brand: Sinemet, Caramet, Lecado, Duodopa (intestinal gel), Sinemet Plus.
description: Co-careldopa is another formulation for Parkinson’s disease combining levodopa with carbidopa. It helps reduce motor symptoms and improves mobility.
dosage:
Typical starting dose: 62.5–125 mg three times daily, titrated based on response.

Modified-release tablets may be used for smoother symptom control.
sideEffects:
Nausea, dizziness, low blood pressure, hallucinations.

Long-term use may cause involuntary movements.
importantInfo:
Take consistently, preferably with a small snack.

Avoid stopping abruptly — taper slowly.

May interact with antipsychotics and iron supplements.

name: Co-codamol
description: Co-codamol is a combination of paracetamol and codeine, used to treat moderate pain when standard painkillers are not effective. Codeine is an opioid that enhances the effect of paracetamol.
dosage:
Standard: 8/500 mg or 30/500 mg tablets.

Take 1–2 tablets every 4–6 hours as needed. Do not exceed 8 tablets per day.
sideEffects:
Constipation, drowsiness, nausea, dizziness.

Prolonged use can lead to dependence or tolerance.
importantInfo:
Do not take with other paracetamol products.

Avoid alcohol and activities requiring alertness.

Use for short-term pain relief unless advised otherwise.

name: Co-codaprin (aspirin and codeine)
description: Co-codaprin is a combination of aspirin and codeine used for short-term relief of moderate pain that is not relieved by aspirin, ibuprofen, or paracetamol alone.
dosage:
Adults: 1–2 tablets every 4–6 hours as needed.

Maximum: 8 tablets in 24 hours.

Not recommended for children under 16 due to aspirin content.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, constipation, stomach irritation.

Rare: allergic reaction, gastrointestinal bleeding.
importantInfo:
Do not take with other NSAIDs or paracetamol/codeine products.

Avoid alcohol while using.

Use the lowest dose for the shortest duration to prevent dependence.

name: Co-dydramol
description: Co-dydramol is a painkiller combining paracetamol with dihydrocodeine. It is used for moderate pain when other pain relievers are not effective.
dosage:
Typical adult dose: 1–2 tablets every 4–6 hours.

Do not exceed 8 tablets in 24 hours.
sideEffects:
Nausea, constipation, dizziness, drowsiness.

Long-term use can lead to tolerance or dependence.
importantInfo:
Avoid other products containing paracetamol.

Do not use for more than a few days unless prescribed.

Avoid alcohol and heavy machinery while taking.

name: Coal tar
description: Coal tar is used to treat psoriasis, eczema, and seborrheic dermatitis. It helps reduce itching, scaling, and inflammation by slowing skin cell growth.
dosage:
Apply to affected areas once or twice daily.

Shampoo: use 1–3 times weekly as directed.
sideEffects:
Skin irritation, staining of clothes or hair, sensitivity to sunlight.

Unpleasant odor is common.
importantInfo:
Avoid excessive sun exposure.

Do not apply to broken or infected skin.

Wash hands thoroughly after use.

name: Codeine
brand: Codeine Phosphate, Codipar, Solpadeine Max, Nurofen Plus (combo), Tylex.
description: Codeine is an opioid painkiller used to treat mild to moderate pain, cough, and sometimes diarrhea. It works by blocking pain signals in the brain and spinal cord.
dosage:
Pain relief: 15–60 mg every 4–6 hours as needed.

Maximum: 240 mg/day.

Always start with the lowest effective dose.
sideEffects:
Constipation, drowsiness, dizziness, nausea.

Prolonged use may cause dependence or withdrawal.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol and other CNS depressants.

Do not exceed recommended dose.

Not suitable for children under 12 or for long-term use without medical supervision.

name: Colchicine
description: Colchicine is used to treat and prevent gout attacks and familial Mediterranean fever. It works by reducing inflammation caused by uric acid crystals in joints.
dosage:
Acute gout: 500 mcg 2–4 times daily until relief or max 6 mg over 3–4 days.

Prevention: 500 mcg once or twice daily.
sideEffects:
Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain.

High doses: bone marrow suppression, nerve or kidney damage.
importantInfo:
Avoid grapefruit juice — may increase side effects.

Take exactly as prescribed.

Not for long-term use unless directed.

name: Colecalciferol
description: Colecalciferol (vitamin D3) is used to prevent and treat vitamin D deficiency, supporting calcium absorption and bone health.
dosage:
Prevention: 400–1,000 IU daily.

Deficiency treatment: 20,000–50,000 IU weekly for 6–8 weeks, followed by maintenance.
sideEffects:
Rare at normal doses: nausea, headache, fatigue.

High doses: hypercalcemia, kidney stones, confusion.
importantInfo:
Take with food for better absorption.

Do not exceed recommended dose.

Monitor calcium levels during high-dose treatment.

name: Contraceptive injections (medroxyprogesterone)
brand: Depo-Provera, Sayana Press, Provera (oral), Cyclofem, Noristerat.
description: Medroxyprogesterone injections are a form of long-acting contraception. They prevent ovulation and alter the uterine lining to prevent pregnancy.
dosage:
150 mg intramuscularly every 12 weeks (Depo-Provera).

104 mg subcutaneously every 13 weeks (Sayana Press).
sideEffects:
Weight gain, irregular periods, delayed fertility return.

Long-term use may reduce bone density.
importantInfo:
Ensure timely repeat injections every 12–13 weeks.

Discuss bone health if used for more than 2 years.

Does not protect against STIs.

name: Cyanocobalamin
description: Cyanocobalamin is a synthetic form of vitamin B12 used to treat or prevent B12 deficiency. It supports red blood cell formation and nerve function.
dosage:
IM injection: 1,000 mcg weekly for 6–8 weeks, then monthly.

Oral: 50–2,000 mcg daily depending on deficiency severity.
sideEffects:
Injection site pain, headache, nausea.

Rare: low potassium, allergic reaction.
importantInfo:
Essential for patients with pernicious anemia or absorption issues.

Monitor B12 and hemoglobin levels regularly.

May be lifelong in some individuals.

name: Cyclizine
description: Cyclizine is an antihistamine used to prevent and treat nausea, vomiting, and vertigo, especially related to motion sickness or post-operative recovery.
dosage:
Adults: 50 mg up to three times a day.

Children 6–12: 25 mg up to three times daily.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision.

Occasionally: headache, dizziness, or allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
May impair concentration — avoid driving or alcohol.

Take 30 minutes before travel for motion sickness.

Not recommended for children under 6.

name: Dabigatran
description: Dabigatran is an oral anticoagulant used to prevent stroke in atrial fibrillation and to treat or prevent deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
dosage:
150 mg twice daily for most adults.

Lower dose (110 mg) may be used in elderly or those with renal impairment.
sideEffects:
Bleeding, indigestion, abdominal pain.

Rare: allergic reactions, liver issues.
importantInfo:
Do not miss doses — clot risk increases.

Avoid NSAIDs unless advised.

No routine blood monitoring, but kidney function should be checked periodically.

name: Dapagliflozin
description: Dapagliflozin is used to treat type 2 diabetes, heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. It helps lower blood sugar and improve cardiovascular and renal outcomes.
dosage:
10 mg once daily, with or without food.

May be used alone or in combination with other diabetes medications.
sideEffects:
Urinary tract infections, genital infections, increased urination.

Rare: dehydration, ketoacidosis, Fournier’s gangrene.
importantInfo:
Stay well hydrated.

Monitor for signs of infection or ketoacidosis (e.g. abdominal pain, vomiting).

Not for use in type 1 diabetes or severe kidney disease.

name: Dexamethasone
description: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used to reduce inflammation in a wide range of conditions including asthma, severe allergies, arthritis, and COVID-19 treatment.
dosage:
Dose depends on condition: 0.5–10 mg daily orally or via injection.

Short courses are common for acute inflammation.
sideEffects:
Increased appetite, mood changes, insomnia.

Long-term: weight gain, osteoporosis, high blood sugar.
importantInfo:
Take with food to reduce stomach upset.

Do not stop suddenly after long-term use — taper gradually.

Monitor for infection or unusual mood changes.

name: Diazepam
description: Diazepam is a benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety, muscle spasms, seizures, and alcohol withdrawal. It works by calming the brain and nerves.
dosage:
Anxiety: 2–10 mg up to 3–4 times daily.

Muscle spasm or alcohol withdrawal: similar dosing as needed.

Seizures: rectal gel or IV/IM in acute settings.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, fatigue, dizziness, blurred vision.

Long-term use: tolerance, dependence, memory issues.
importantInfo:
Use short term unless advised otherwise.

Avoid alcohol and do not drive while taking.

Taper slowly to avoid withdrawal.

name: Diclofenac
description: Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to relieve pain and inflammation in conditions such as arthritis, sprains, and menstrual cramps.
dosage:
Typical dose: 50 mg two or three times daily.

Maximum: 150 mg per day.

Topical gels available for local relief.
sideEffects:
Indigestion, stomach pain, headache.

Serious: ulcers, bleeding, cardiovascular risk.
importantInfo:
Take with food to reduce stomach upset.

Avoid other NSAIDs while using.

Not recommended for people with heart disease or GI history.

name: Digoxin
description: Digoxin is used to treat heart failure and atrial fibrillation. It increases the force of heart contractions and slows the heart rate.
dosage:
Typical maintenance: 125–250 mcg once daily.

Dose adjusted based on kidney function and blood levels.
sideEffects:
Nausea, dizziness, blurred vision, confusion.

Toxicity: irregular heartbeat, vomiting, vision changes.
importantInfo:
Monitor blood levels regularly.

Avoid taking with high-fiber meals or antacids close to dosing.

Watch for signs of toxicity — seek help if suspected.

name: Dihydrocodeine
brand: DF118 Forte, DHC Continus, Co-dydramol (combo), Paracodol, Synap Forte.
description: Dihydrocodeine is an opioid painkiller used for moderate to severe pain. It works similarly to codeine but may be more effective in some cases.
dosage:
Standard dose: 30 mg every 4–6 hours.

Modified release: 60–120 mg every 12 hours.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, constipation, nausea, dry mouth.

Prolonged use: dependence, tolerance, withdrawal symptoms.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol and driving.

Use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration.

Not recommended for long-term use unless supervised.

name: Diltiazem
description: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to treat high blood pressure, angina, and some heart rhythm disorders. It relaxes blood vessels and reduces heart rate.
dosage:
Typical oral dose: 120–360 mg daily, in divided or extended-release form.

Dose adjusted based on response and condition treated.
sideEffects:
Dizziness, headache, flushing, slow heart rate.

Less common: swollen ankles, fatigue, rash.
importantInfo:
Do not crush extended-release tablets.

Avoid grapefruit juice — may increase blood levels.

Monitor heart rate and blood pressure regularly.

name: Diphenhydramine
description: Diphenhydramine is a sedating antihistamine used for allergies, cold symptoms, and short-term treatment of insomnia. It also relieves motion sickness and nausea.
dosage:
Allergy or sleep aid: 25–50 mg at bedtime.

Motion sickness: 25–50 mg every 6–8 hours as needed.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dry mouth, dizziness, blurred vision.

Can impair thinking and coordination.
importantInfo:
Do not mix with alcohol or other sedatives.

Not recommended for long-term sleep use.

Avoid in children under 6 unless advised.

name: Dipyridamole
brand: Persantin, Dipyridamole Mylan, Asasantin (with aspirin), Dipyridamole Accord.
description: Dipyridamole is an antiplatelet and vasodilator used to prevent stroke, often in combination with aspirin. It also improves blood flow during cardiac stress testing.
dosage:
Stroke prevention: 200 mg modified-release twice daily with aspirin.

Cardiac testing: IV infusion in hospital setting.
sideEffects:
Headache, dizziness, stomach upset, flushing.

Rare: low blood pressure, bleeding.
importantInfo:
Take modified-release capsules whole.

Avoid caffeine before stress testing.

Monitor for signs of bleeding if combined with other anticoagulants.

name: Docusate
description: Docusate is a stool softener used to relieve occasional constipation. It works by increasing water absorption into the stool, making it easier to pass.
dosage:
Adults: 100–200 mg once or twice daily.

Children: dosage depends on age — follow packaging or doctor’s advice.
sideEffects:
Stomach cramps, diarrhea, bitter taste.

Rare: throat irritation (liquid form).
importantInfo:
Stay well hydrated during use.

Not for long-term use unless prescribed.

Discontinue if diarrhea or cramping occurs.

name: Domperidone
description: Domperidone is a medication used to relieve nausea, vomiting, bloating, and stomach discomfort by increasing the movement of the stomach and intestines.
dosage:
10 mg up to three times daily, 15–30 minutes before meals.

Do not exceed 30 mg in 24 hours without medical advice.
sideEffects:
Dry mouth, abdominal cramps, dizziness.

Rare: irregular heartbeat or QT prolongation.
importantInfo:
Do not use long term unless advised.

Avoid if you have heart rhythm disorders.

Report chest pain or fainting immediately.

name: Donepezil
description: Donepezil is used to treat symptoms of Alzheimer's disease. It works by increasing levels of acetylcholine in the brain to improve memory and cognitive function.
dosage:
Start with 5 mg once daily at bedtime.

May increase to 10 mg daily after 4–6 weeks if tolerated.
sideEffects:
Nausea, diarrhea, insomnia, muscle cramps.

Serious: fainting, slow heart rate, seizures.
importantInfo:
Take at bedtime to reduce nausea.

May take a few weeks for effects to be noticeable.

Continue even if no immediate improvement is seen.

name: Dosulepin
description: Dosulepin is a tricyclic antidepressant used to treat depression and anxiety. It works by increasing the levels of serotonin and norepinephrine in the brain.
dosage:
Typical dose: 75–150 mg daily in divided doses or once at bedtime.

Start low and increase gradually under supervision.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision.

Overdose can be fatal — use with caution.
importantInfo:
Not a first-line antidepressant — reserved for cases not responding to others.

Avoid alcohol and driving.

Do not stop suddenly without medical advice.

name: Doxazosin
description: Doxazosin is an alpha-blocker used to treat high blood pressure and symptoms of an enlarged prostate (BPH). It relaxes blood vessels and urinary tract muscles.
dosage:
Initial dose: 1 mg once daily.

Maintenance: 2–8 mg daily depending on response.
sideEffects:
Dizziness, fatigue, headache, low blood pressure.

First dose may cause fainting — known as 'first-dose effect'.
importantInfo:
Take at bedtime to reduce dizziness.

Stand up slowly to avoid lightheadedness.

Monitor blood pressure regularly.

name: Doxycycline
description: Doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic used to treat a variety of infections, including respiratory tract infections, acne, and sexually transmitted diseases.
dosage:
Typical dose: 100 mg once or twice daily.

Initial dose may be 200 mg followed by maintenance dosing.
sideEffects:
Nausea, sun sensitivity, upset stomach.

Rare: esophageal irritation, tooth discoloration (children).
importantInfo:
Take with plenty of water and remain upright for 30 minutes.

Avoid milk, antacids, or supplements containing calcium or iron close to dosing.

Not recommended during pregnancy or for children under 8.

name: Duloxetine
description: Duloxetine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used to treat depression, anxiety, nerve pain, and fibromyalgia.
dosage:
Typical dose: 30–60 mg once daily.

Maximum: 120 mg per day for some conditions.
sideEffects:
Nausea, dry mouth, fatigue, increased sweating.

May raise blood pressure or cause withdrawal symptoms if stopped abruptly.
importantInfo:
Do not stop suddenly — taper gradually under medical guidance.

Monitor for mood changes or suicidal thoughts, especially early in treatment.

May take a few weeks for full effects.

name: Edoxaban
description: Edoxaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) used to prevent stroke in atrial fibrillation and treat or prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
dosage:
Typical dose: 60 mg once daily.

Reduced to 30 mg daily in patients with renal impairment or low body weight.
sideEffects:
Bleeding, bruising, anemia.

Rare: liver enzyme changes or allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Do not miss doses or stop without consulting your doctor.

Avoid NSAIDs or aspirin unless prescribed.

No routine blood monitoring required, but kidney function should be checked.

name: Empagliflozin
description: Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor used to treat type 2 diabetes, heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. It helps reduce blood sugar by promoting glucose excretion in urine.
dosage:
Starting dose: 10 mg once daily.

May be increased to 25 mg once daily if needed.
sideEffects:
Urinary tract infections, genital infections, increased urination.

Rare: dehydration, ketoacidosis, Fournier’s gangrene.
importantInfo:
Drink plenty of fluids.

Monitor for unusual symptoms like abdominal pain or weakness.

Not suitable for type 1 diabetes or during active infections.

name: Enalapril
description: Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure, heart failure, and kidney problems in people with diabetes. It helps relax blood vessels.
dosage:
Hypertension: 5–20 mg once or twice daily.

Heart failure: start with 2.5 mg and titrate based on tolerance and kidney function.
sideEffects:
Dry cough, dizziness, headache.

Rare: high potassium, kidney dysfunction, angioedema.
importantInfo:
Monitor kidney function and potassium.

Avoid potassium supplements unless advised.

Inform your doctor if you experience swelling of the face or lips.

name: Eplerenone
description: Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic used to treat heart failure and high blood pressure. It works by blocking aldosterone receptors.
dosage:
Heart failure: 25 mg once daily, may increase to 50 mg.

Hypertension: 50 mg once daily, max 100 mg/day.
sideEffects:
High potassium, dizziness, diarrhea.

Rare: breast tenderness or enlargement, especially in men.
importantInfo:
Monitor potassium and kidney function regularly.

Avoid potassium-rich foods or supplements.

Use caution with other medications that raise potassium.

name: Erythromycin
description: Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic used to treat chest infections, skin infections, and STIs. It’s often used when patients are allergic to penicillin.
dosage:
Typical adult dose: 250–500 mg every 6 hours.

Children’s dosing is weight-based and varies by infection.
sideEffects:
Nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhea.

Can cause liver issues or QT prolongation in rare cases.
importantInfo:
Take with or just after food.

Avoid with certain heart or seizure medications — check with your doctor.

Finish the course even if you feel better.

name: Escitalopram
description: Escitalopram is an SSRI antidepressant used to treat depression and generalized anxiety disorder. It increases serotonin levels in the brain.
dosage:
Starting dose: 10 mg once daily.

May be increased to 20 mg daily depending on response.
sideEffects:
Nausea, headache, insomnia, sexual dysfunction.

May initially increase anxiety or agitation.
importantInfo:
May take several weeks to take full effect.

Avoid stopping suddenly — taper under medical supervision.

Monitor for mood changes, especially in the first few weeks.

name: Esomeprazole
description: Esomeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) used to treat acid reflux, heartburn, ulcers, and conditions involving excessive stomach acid.
dosage:
Typical dose: 20–40 mg once daily.

Some cases (e.g. ulcers or H. pylori treatment) may require twice-daily dosing temporarily.
sideEffects:
Headache, abdominal pain, constipation, dry mouth.

Long-term: risk of low magnesium, B12 deficiency, fractures.
importantInfo:
Take at least 30 minutes before meals.

Do not crush or chew tablets.

Use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration.

name: Ezetimibe
description: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol-lowering medication that reduces absorption of cholesterol from the small intestine. It is often used with statins.
dosage:
10 mg once daily, with or without food.

Can be used alone or in combination with a statin.
sideEffects:
Muscle pain, fatigue, diarrhea.

Rare: liver enzyme elevation, allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Liver function should be monitored if used with statins.

Report unexplained muscle pain or weakness.

Maintain a cholesterol-lowering diet alongside medication.

name: Felodipine
description: Felodipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat high blood pressure and angina. It relaxes blood vessels and improves blood flow.
dosage:
Initial dose: 5 mg once daily.

May be adjusted between 2.5–10 mg depending on response.
sideEffects:
Flushing, headache, swollen ankles, dizziness.

Less common: fatigue or palpitations.
importantInfo:
Take at the same time daily, preferably in the morning.

Avoid grapefruit juice — it increases drug levels.

Do not crush or chew extended-release tablets.

name: Fentanyl
description: Fentanyl is a powerful opioid used to treat severe pain, especially in cancer patients. It is available as patches, lozenges, and injections.
dosage:
Transdermal patch: 12–100 mcg/hour changed every 72 hours.

Dose depends on previous opioid use and pain severity.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, constipation, nausea, respiratory depression.

High risk of overdose or dependence.
importantInfo:
Use exactly as prescribed — overdose can be fatal.

Avoid heat sources near patches.

Store securely and dispose of used patches safely.

name: Ferrous fumarate
brand: Fersaday, Galfer FA, Ferrograd F, Ferrous-F, Haem Feron.
description: Ferrous fumarate is an iron supplement used to treat and prevent iron-deficiency anemia. It helps replenish iron stores needed for red blood cell production.
dosage:
Typical adult dose: 200–210 mg once or twice daily.

Take 30–60 minutes before meals for best absorption.
sideEffects:
Constipation, dark stools, nausea, abdominal discomfort.

Rare: allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Take with vitamin C or orange juice to improve absorption.

Avoid taking with tea, milk, or antacids.

Keep out of reach of children — iron overdose can be fatal.

name: Ferrous sulfate
description: Ferrous sulfate is a common iron supplement used to treat iron-deficiency anemia. It increases the levels of iron in the blood to support oxygen transport.
dosage:
Usual dose: 200 mg one to three times daily.

Often taken for at least 3 months to replenish iron stores.
sideEffects:
Stomach upset, constipation, dark stools.

Rare: metallic taste, allergic reaction.
importantInfo:
Take on an empty stomach for better absorption.

Do not take with tea, dairy, or calcium supplements.

Swallow whole tablets — do not crush or chew.

name: Fexofenadine
description: Fexofenadine is a non-drowsy antihistamine used to treat allergies such as hay fever, urticaria, and seasonal rhinitis.
dosage:
Adults: 120–180 mg once daily.

Children’s dose varies by age — typically 30–60 mg once or twice daily.
sideEffects:
Headache, nausea, drowsiness (rare), dizziness.

Occasionally: dry mouth or indigestion.
importantInfo:
Avoid grapefruit juice — may reduce absorption.

Take with water on an empty stomach if possible.

Do not exceed the recommended dose.

name: Finasteride
description: Finasteride is used to treat enlarged prostate (BPH) and male-pattern hair loss by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to DHT.
dosage:
BPH: 5 mg once daily.

Hair loss: 1 mg once daily.
sideEffects:
Decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, breast tenderness.

Rare: depression, allergic reaction, breast lumps.
importantInfo:
Not for use by women or children.

Pregnant women should not handle crushed tablets.

May take 3–6 months for noticeable effect.

name: Flucloxacillin
description: Flucloxacillin is a penicillin-type antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as skin infections, bone infections, and infected wounds.
dosage:
Typical adult dose: 250–500 mg four times daily.

Best taken on an empty stomach, 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals.
sideEffects:
Nausea, diarrhea, skin rash.

Rare: liver enzyme changes, allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Complete the full course even if symptoms improve.

Inform your doctor if allergic to penicillin.

Take doses evenly spaced throughout the day.

name: Fluconazole
brand: Diflucan, Canesten Oral, Flucoral, Flucan, Zocon.
description: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat yeast infections, thrush, and systemic fungal infections. It works by stopping fungal growth.
dosage:
Common dose for thrush: 150 mg single dose.

Other infections: 50–400 mg once daily, depending on severity.
sideEffects:
Headache, nausea, stomach pain, rash.

Rare: liver issues, allergic reactions, QT prolongation.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol while taking this medication.

May interact with other drugs — inform your doctor of all medications.

Take at the same time each day if using longer term.

name: Fluoxetine (Prozac)
description: Fluoxetine is an SSRI antidepressant used to treat depression, OCD, bulimia nervosa, and panic disorder by increasing serotonin levels in the brain.
dosage:
Starting dose: 20 mg once daily.

May be increased to a maximum of 60 mg/day depending on condition.
sideEffects:
Nausea, insomnia, headache, anxiety, sexual dysfunction.

May increase suicidal thoughts in young adults.
importantInfo:
May take 2–4 weeks for full effect.

Avoid abrupt discontinuation — taper if stopping.

Monitor mood, especially early in treatment.

name: Fluticasone
description: Fluticasone is a corticosteroid used to treat asthma, allergic rhinitis, and skin conditions. It reduces inflammation and swelling in affected areas.
dosage:
Inhaler: 100–500 mcg twice daily based on severity.

Nasal spray: 1–2 sprays per nostril daily.

Topical: apply thinly 1–2 times daily as prescribed.
sideEffects:
Hoarseness, throat irritation, oral thrush.

Topical use may cause skin thinning if overused.
importantInfo:
Rinse mouth after inhaler use to prevent thrush.

Do not use nasal spray for more than 6 weeks without review.

Apply skin creams sparingly and avoid eyes.

name: Folic acid
description: Folic acid is a form of vitamin B9 used to treat or prevent folate deficiency anemia and to support pregnancy and fetal development.
dosage:
Deficiency: 5 mg once daily.

Pregnancy: 400–800 mcg daily, starting before conception and through the first trimester.
sideEffects:
Generally well tolerated.

Rare: rash, stomach upset, allergic reaction.
importantInfo:
Essential in pregnancy to prevent neural tube defects.

May be combined with iron supplements.

Take consistently for full benefit.

name: Furosemide
description: Furosemide is a loop diuretic used to treat fluid retention (edema) and high blood pressure. It works by helping the kidneys remove excess fluid.
dosage:
Edema: 20–80 mg once or twice daily.

Hypertension: lower doses, often combined with other drugs.
sideEffects:
Frequent urination, dizziness, low potassium, dehydration.

Rare: gout, hearing loss with high doses.
importantInfo:
Take in the morning to avoid nighttime urination.

Monitor electrolytes and kidney function.

Stay well hydrated unless otherwise advised.

name: Fusidic acid
description: Fusidic acid is an antibiotic used topically or in eye drops to treat skin infections such as impetigo and infected dermatitis.
dosage:
Apply thinly to affected area 2–3 times daily.

Eye drops: 1 drop twice daily for up to 7 days.
sideEffects:
Skin irritation, stinging, mild rash.

Rare: allergic reaction or resistance with long-term use.
importantInfo:
Do not use for longer than 1–2 weeks without medical advice.

Avoid contact with eyes unless using eye-specific formulation.

Wash hands after application.

name: Fybogel (ispaghula husk)
description: Fybogel is a bulk-forming laxative used to treat constipation and maintain regular bowel movements. It contains ispaghula husk, a natural source of fiber.
dosage:
Adults: 1 sachet in water twice daily after meals.

Children: half dosage, based on age and response.
sideEffects:
Bloating, flatulence, stomach cramps.

Rare: allergic reactions or blockage if not taken with enough water.
importantInfo:
Always take with a full glass of water.

Do not take before bedtime.

Allow 12–24 hours for effect, may take up to 3 days.

name: Gabapentin
description: Gabapentin is used to treat nerve pain, epilepsy, and sometimes anxiety. It works by affecting nerve signals in the brain.
dosage:
Initial dose: 300 mg once daily, increased gradually up to 1,800–3,600 mg daily in divided doses.

Titrate based on response and tolerance.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dizziness, fatigue, swelling in hands/feet.

May affect coordination or mood.
importantInfo:
Do not stop abruptly — risk of seizures.

Take at the same times daily.

Avoid alcohol and driving until you know how it affects you.

name: Gaviscon (alginic acid)
description: Gaviscon contains alginic acid and antacids to relieve heartburn, indigestion, and acid reflux by forming a protective barrier over stomach contents.
dosage:
10–20 ml (2–4 teaspoons) after meals and at bedtime.

Chewable tablets: 2–4 tablets after meals and at bedtime.
sideEffects:
Rare: bloating, nausea, taste changes.

Generally well tolerated.
importantInfo:
Do not take with large amounts of water immediately after dosing.

Safe for use in pregnancy.

Avoid taking other medications within 2 hours of use.

name: Gliclazide
description: Gliclazide is a sulfonylurea used to treat type 2 diabetes. It helps the pancreas release more insulin to lower blood sugar levels.
dosage:
Modified-release: 30–120 mg once daily with breakfast.

Immediate-release: 40–160 mg once or twice daily.
sideEffects:
Low blood sugar, weight gain, nausea.

Rare: liver enzyme changes, allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Take with food to avoid low blood sugar.

Monitor blood glucose regularly.

Do not skip meals while using this medication.

name: Glimepiride
description: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea used for managing type 2 diabetes by stimulating insulin release from the pancreas.
dosage:
Start with 1 mg daily before breakfast.

Maintenance: 1–4 mg daily; max 6 mg/day depending on response.
sideEffects:
Low blood sugar, weight gain, nausea.

Rare: rash, liver function changes.
importantInfo:
Take with food to prevent hypoglycemia.

Avoid alcohol — can affect blood sugar control.

Monitor blood sugar regularly and carry sugar if prone to lows.

name: Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN)
description: GTN is used to relieve chest pain (angina) and manage anal fissures. It works by widening blood vessels to improve blood flow and reduce heart strain.
dosage:
Sublingual spray/tablet: 300–600 mcg under tongue as needed for chest pain.

Rectal ointment: apply small amount twice daily for anal fissures.
sideEffects:
Headache, dizziness, flushing.

May cause low blood pressure or fainting.
importantInfo:
Sit down before using for angina to avoid dizziness.

Do not use with erectile dysfunction drugs — risk of serious drop in blood pressure.

Store spray in original container away from heat.

name: Haloperidol
description: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia, severe agitation, psychosis, and sometimes Tourette’s syndrome or acute nausea.
dosage:
Oral: 1–15 mg daily in divided doses.

Intramuscular for acute agitation: 2–10 mg as needed.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, restlessness, tremors, dry mouth.

Serious: movement disorders (e.g., tardive dyskinesia), QT prolongation.
importantInfo:
Regularly monitor for side effects during long-term use.

Avoid alcohol and driving.

Not typically first-line for elderly patients with dementia.

name: Heparinoid
description: Heparinoid creams and gels are used to treat bruises, sprains, and superficial thrombophlebitis. They help reduce inflammation and improve blood flow in the affected area.
dosage:
Apply 2–3 times daily to the affected area.

Massage in gently unless otherwise instructed.
sideEffects:
Skin irritation, redness, itching.

Rare: allergic reaction.
importantInfo:
Do not apply to broken or infected skin.

Avoid contact with eyes or mucous membranes.

Wash hands after use.

name: Hormone replacement therapy (HRT)
description: HRT is used to relieve menopausal symptoms by replacing declining hormone levels (estrogen and sometimes progesterone). It can be oral, transdermal, or vaginal.
dosage: Depends on formulation — typically daily pills, patches changed twice weekly, or gels applied daily.
sideEffects:
Breast tenderness, mood changes, headache, bloating.

Increased risk of blood clots and certain cancers with prolonged use.
importantInfo:
Review treatment annually with a doctor.

Report unusual vaginal bleeding, breast lumps, or persistent pain.

Use lowest effective dose for the shortest duration.

name: Hydrocortisone
description: Hydrocortisone is a corticosteroid used for inflammation, allergic reactions, and adrenal insufficiency. Available as tablets, creams, injections, and suppositories.
dosage:
Topical: apply thinly 1–2 times daily.

Oral: 10–30 mg/day for adrenal insufficiency (divided doses).

Dose depends on condition and formulation.
sideEffects:
Skin thinning (topical), increased appetite, mood changes, insomnia.

Long-term use: osteoporosis, adrenal suppression.
importantInfo:
Do not stop oral treatment suddenly — taper gradually.

Apply topical forms sparingly and avoid eyes.

Monitor for infection or weight gain if using long term.

name: Hydroxocobalamin
description: Hydroxocobalamin is a long-acting form of vitamin B12 used to treat and prevent B12 deficiency, especially in pernicious anemia.
dosage:
1,000 mcg intramuscularly every 2–3 months (maintenance).

Initial treatment: multiple doses over the first few weeks.
sideEffects:
Injection site pain, redness, mild diarrhea.

Rare: allergic reaction, low potassium.
importantInfo:
Essential for nerve and blood cell health.

Safe for use in pregnancy.

Monitor B12 and hemoglobin levels during treatment.

name: Hydroxychloroquine
brand: Plaquenil, Quinoric, Axemal, Zentiva HCQ, Dolquine.
description: Hydroxychloroquine is used to treat autoimmune diseases like lupus and rheumatoid arthritis, and as a malaria prophylactic. It modifies immune response and inflammation.
dosage:
RA/Lupus: 200–400 mg once daily or divided doses.

Malaria prevention: 400 mg once weekly.
sideEffects:
Nausea, headache, visual disturbances.

Long-term: retinal damage, muscle weakness.
importantInfo:
Requires regular eye exams during prolonged use.

Take with food to reduce stomach upset.

Report visual changes promptly.

name: Hyoscine hydrobromide (Kwells and Joy-Rides)
description: Hyoscine hydrobromide is used to prevent motion sickness and treat nausea. It works by blocking signals from the inner ear to the vomiting center in the brain.
dosage:
Adults: 300–600 mcg every 6–8 hours.

Children: 150–300 mcg depending on age and formulation.
sideEffects:
Dry mouth, blurred vision, drowsiness, constipation.

Rare: confusion, especially in older adults.
importantInfo:
May cause drowsiness — avoid driving.

Take 30–60 minutes before travel for best effect.

Avoid alcohol and use with caution in glaucoma or urinary retention.

name: Ibuprofen
description: Ibuprofen is an everyday painkiller for a range of aches and pains, including back pain, period pain, toothache and symptoms of colds, flu or coronavirus (COVID-19). It also treats inflammation such as sprains and strains, and pain from arthritis.
dosage:
For adults, the typical dosage is 200–400 mg taken every 4 to 6 hours as needed.

For children, the dosage depends on age and weight. Typically, 5–10 mg per kg of body weight every 6 to 8 hours is recommended, not to exceed 40 mg/kg per day.

Patients are advised to start with the lowest effective dose and adjust based on the severity of symptoms.
sideEffects:
Common side effects may include: nausea, dizziness, headache, and stomach upset.

More rarely: gastrointestinal bleeding, ulcers, kidney issues, or allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Take with food or milk to reduce stomach irritation.

Avoid using with other NSAIDs.

Long-term use may increase risks of heart, kidney, or stomach issues. Consult your doctor before making any changes, especially if you have health conditions or take other meds.

name: Indapamide
description: Indapamide is a thiazide-like diuretic used to treat high blood pressure and fluid retention by helping the kidneys remove excess sodium and water.
dosage:
Hypertension: 1.5 mg modified-release once daily.

Edema: 2.5 mg once daily, adjusted as needed.
sideEffects:
Dizziness, low potassium, dehydration, increased urination.

Rare: rash, sensitivity to sunlight.
importantInfo:
Take in the morning to avoid nighttime urination.

Monitor kidney function and electrolytes.

Use caution in diabetes and gout.

name: Insulin
description: Insulin is a hormone used to manage blood glucose in people with diabetes. It is classified by action type: rapid-acting, short-acting, intermediate, and long-acting.
dosage:
Highly individualized based on blood glucose levels, diet, and activity.

Administered subcutaneously — frequency varies by type (e.g., basal-bolus regimens).
sideEffects:
Low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), weight gain, injection site reactions.

Rare: allergic reactions, lipodystrophy.
importantInfo:
Rotate injection sites.

Monitor blood sugar regularly.

Always carry fast-acting sugar and know signs of hypoglycemia.

name: Irbesartan
description: Irbesartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) used to treat high blood pressure and protect kidneys in people with diabetes.
dosage:
Typical starting dose: 150 mg once daily.

May be increased to 300 mg daily based on response.
sideEffects:
Dizziness, fatigue, low blood pressure.

Rare: high potassium, kidney function decline.
importantInfo:
Monitor blood pressure, potassium, and kidney function regularly.

Avoid potassium supplements unless advised.

Take at the same time daily, with or without food.

name: Isosorbide mononitrate and isosorbide dinitrate
description: Isosorbide mononitrate and dinitrate are nitrates used to prevent chest pain (angina) by relaxing blood vessels and improving oxygen flow to the heart.
dosage:
Mononitrate: 20–60 mg once or twice daily.

Dinitrate: 10–40 mg two to three times daily.

Extended-release formulations are also available.
sideEffects:
Headache, dizziness, flushing, low blood pressure.

Tolerance may develop with continuous use.
importantInfo:
Do not use with PDE5 inhibitors (e.g. Viagra).

Leave a nitrate-free interval (usually overnight) to reduce tolerance.

Sit or lie down if dizziness occurs.

name: Isotretinoin (Roaccutane)
description: Isotretinoin (Roaccutane) is a powerful retinoid used to treat severe acne. It reduces oil production and inflammation in the skin.
dosage:
Typically 0.5–1 mg/kg/day for 16–24 weeks.

Dosage adjusted based on response and side effects.
sideEffects:
Dry skin/lips, joint pain, mood changes.

Serious: birth defects if used during pregnancy.
importantInfo:
Strict pregnancy prevention required during and after use.

Regular blood tests needed for liver function and lipids.

Avoid vitamin A supplements and limit sun exposure.

name: Isotretinoin (Isotrex)
description: Topical isotretinoin is used for mild to moderate acne. It helps to unclog pores and reduce skin inflammation.
dosage:
Apply a thin layer once or twice daily to affected skin.

Avoid broken or irritated skin.
sideEffects:
Skin irritation, redness, peeling, photosensitivity.

May worsen acne initially before improvement.
importantInfo:
Use sunscreen and avoid excessive sun.

Do not apply near eyes or lips.

Wash hands after application and avoid harsh skin products.

name: Ketoconazole
description: Ketoconazole is an antifungal used topically for fungal skin infections and seborrheic dermatitis, and sometimes orally for serious fungal infections.
dosage:
Topical: apply once or twice daily for 2–4 weeks.

Shampoo: 2% used 2–3 times a week.

Oral (rarely): 200–400 mg daily under strict supervision.
sideEffects:
Skin irritation (topical), nausea, headache.

Oral: liver toxicity, hormonal effects.
importantInfo:
Topical use is generally safe — avoid contact with eyes.

Oral form requires liver function monitoring.

Do not use other antifungal creams unless advised.

name: Labetalol
description: Labetalol is a combined alpha- and beta-blocker used to treat high blood pressure, including during pregnancy and hypertensive emergencies.
dosage:
Oral: 100–400 mg twice daily.

IV (for emergencies): 20 mg over 2 minutes, followed by further dosing as needed.
sideEffects:
Dizziness, fatigue, nausea, cold hands/feet.

Rare: shortness of breath or slow heart rate.
importantInfo:
Do not stop abruptly — taper gradually.

Monitor blood pressure regularly.

Use caution in asthma or heart conditions.

name: Lactulose
description: Lactulose is a synthetic sugar used as a laxative to treat constipation and hepatic encephalopathy. It draws water into the colon and softens stools.
dosage:
Constipation: 15–45 ml daily initially, adjusted based on response.

Hepatic encephalopathy: up to 30–45 ml three to four times daily.
sideEffects: Flatulence, bloating, stomach cramps, diarrhea (at high doses).
importantInfo:
May take 1–2 days for full effect.

Ensure adequate fluid intake.

Do not use for more than a few days without medical advice.

name: Lamotrigine
description: Lamotrigine is an anticonvulsant used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder. It stabilizes electrical activity in the brain.
dosage:
Start with 25 mg once daily, gradually increased over weeks.

Maintenance dose: 100–400 mg/day in divided doses.
sideEffects:
Headache, dizziness, nausea, blurred vision.

Serious: rash, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
importantInfo:
Increase dose slowly to reduce risk of rash.

Inform your doctor if any skin rash appears.

Do not stop abruptly — risk of seizures.

name: Lansoprazole
description: Lansoprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that reduces stomach acid. It’s used for reflux, ulcers, and Helicobacter pylori treatment.
dosage:
Typical adult dose: 15–30 mg once daily.

May be increased to 30 mg twice daily for severe cases.
sideEffects:
Headache, diarrhea, abdominal pain.

Long-term: vitamin B12 or magnesium deficiency, fracture risk.
importantInfo:
Take 30 minutes before meals.

Do not crush or chew capsules.

Use for shortest duration necessary unless advised otherwise.

name: Latanoprost
brand: Xalatan, Monopost, Xalacom (combo), Latanest, Latanoprost Sandoz.
description: Latanoprost is an eye drop used to treat high pressure in the eye caused by glaucoma or ocular hypertension. It increases the drainage of fluid from the eye.
dosage:
1 drop in the affected eye(s) once daily in the evening.

Do not use more than once daily.
sideEffects:
Eye irritation, redness, eyelash growth, darkening of the iris.

Rare: blurred vision, eye pain.
importantInfo:
Remove contact lenses before use and wait 15 minutes before reinserting.
