Continue using even if symptoms improve.

Store in the refrigerator before opening, room temp after.

name: Lercanidipine
description: Lercanidipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat high blood pressure. It works by relaxing blood vessels, reducing strain on the heart.
dosage:
Typical dose: 10–20 mg once daily.

Take 15–30 minutes before a meal.
sideEffects:
Swollen ankles, headache, flushing, dizziness.

Rare: palpitations, rash.
importantInfo:
Avoid grapefruit juice — may increase side effects.

Monitor blood pressure regularly.

Do not crush or chew tablets.

name: Letrozole
description: Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor used to treat hormone-sensitive breast cancer in postmenopausal women by lowering estrogen levels.
dosage:
2.5 mg once daily, usually for 5 years.

Duration may vary based on cancer type and risk.
sideEffects:
Hot flushes, fatigue, joint pain, bone thinning.

Less common: dizziness, insomnia.
importantInfo:
Regular bone density scans may be needed.

Take at the same time daily.

Tell your doctor if you have liver or bone issues.

name: Levetiracetam
description: Levetiracetam is an anticonvulsant used to treat epilepsy by stabilizing electrical activity in the brain.
dosage:
Initial dose: 500 mg twice daily.

Maintenance: up to 1,500 mg twice daily depending on response.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dizziness, fatigue, irritability.

Rare: mood changes, suicidal thoughts.
importantInfo:
Do not stop abruptly — may increase seizure risk.

Inform doctor of mood changes or behavioral symptoms.

Can be taken with or without food.

name: Levothyroxine
description: Levothyroxine is a synthetic form of the thyroid hormone thyroxine (T4), used to treat hypothyroidism by restoring normal hormone levels.
dosage:
Initial dose: 25–50 mcg once daily.

Maintenance: 50–200 mcg daily, adjusted based on TSH levels.
sideEffects:
Palpitations, anxiety, weight loss, heat intolerance.

Overdose: symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
importantInfo:
Take on an empty stomach, 30–60 minutes before breakfast.

Do not take with calcium, iron, or antacids — may affect absorption.

Monitor thyroid levels regularly.

name: Lidocaine
description: Lidocaine is a local anesthetic used to numb tissue in a specific area. It is available in creams, gels, sprays, injections, and patches.
dosage:
Topical: apply thinly as directed.

Injections: administered by healthcare professional based on procedure.
sideEffects:
Tingling, redness, swelling at site.

Rare: dizziness, allergic reaction, irregular heartbeat (with large doses).
importantInfo:
Use only on intact skin unless advised.

Avoid exceeding maximum dose to prevent toxicity.

Wash hands after application unless treating hands.

name: Linagliptin
description: Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor used to treat type 2 diabetes by increasing insulin secretion and decreasing glucagon levels in the blood.
dosage:
5 mg once daily, with or without food.

No dose adjustment required in renal impairment.
sideEffects:
Nasopharyngitis, headache, cough.

Rare: pancreatitis, joint pain, allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Monitor blood sugar regularly.

Inform your doctor of severe abdominal pain or rash.

Not for type 1 diabetes or ketoacidosis.

name: Lisinopril
description: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure, heart failure, and after heart attacks. It relaxes blood vessels and lowers strain on the heart.
dosage:
Initial dose: 5–10 mg once daily.

Maintenance: 10–40 mg once daily depending on condition and response.
sideEffects:
Dry cough, dizziness, low blood pressure.

Rare: angioedema, high potassium, kidney dysfunction.
importantInfo:
Monitor kidney function and potassium.

Avoid potassium supplements unless advised.

Do not take during pregnancy — risk to fetus.

name: Lithium
description: Lithium is a mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder and sometimes recurrent depression. It helps reduce mood swings and prevent manic or depressive episodes.
dosage:
Highly individualized based on blood levels.

Typical maintenance: 400–1,200 mg daily in divided doses.
sideEffects:
Tremor, thirst, nausea, weight gain.

Toxicity: confusion, vomiting, unsteady gait, seizures.
importantInfo:
Requires regular blood monitoring for levels, kidney, and thyroid function.

Maintain consistent salt and fluid intake.

Avoid NSAIDs and dehydration — can increase lithium levels.

name: Loperamide (Imodium)
description: Loperamide is used to treat diarrhea by slowing intestinal movement and reducing stool frequency.
dosage:
Initial dose: 4 mg, followed by 2 mg after each loose stool.

Maximum: 16 mg per day in adults.
sideEffects:
Constipation, nausea, stomach cramps, dizziness.

Rare: bowel obstruction, drowsiness.
importantInfo:
Do not use for more than 2 days unless advised.

Avoid if diarrhea is due to infection or fever.

Drink fluids to prevent dehydration.

name: Loratadine (Clarityn)
description: Loratadine is a non-drowsy antihistamine used for hay fever, allergies, and hives. It blocks the action of histamine to reduce symptoms.
dosage:
Adults and children over 12: 10 mg once daily.

Children 2–12: 5 mg once daily (based on weight).
sideEffects:
Headache, fatigue, dry mouth.

Rare: allergic reaction or drowsiness.
importantInfo:
Usually does not cause drowsiness.

Can be taken with or without food.

Avoid taking more than directed.

name: Lorazepam
description: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety, insomnia, and seizures. It has a calming effect on the brain.
dosage:
Anxiety: 1–4 mg daily in divided doses.

Sleep: 1–2 mg at bedtime.

IV: used for acute seizures or agitation in hospital.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dizziness, weakness.

Risk of dependence, withdrawal, confusion (especially in elderly).
importantInfo:
Short-term use only unless advised.

Avoid alcohol and driving.

Taper gradually to avoid withdrawal symptoms.

name: Losartan
description: Losartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) used to treat high blood pressure, heart failure, and kidney protection in diabetes.
dosage:
Typical dose: 50 mg once daily.

May be increased to 100 mg daily based on response.
sideEffects:
Dizziness, fatigue, low blood pressure.

Rare: high potassium, kidney function decline.
importantInfo:
Monitor blood pressure, kidney function, and potassium.

Avoid potassium supplements or salt substitutes unless advised.

Take at the same time each day.

name: Lymecycline
description: Lymecycline is a tetracycline antibiotic commonly used to treat acne and various bacterial infections including chest and urinary infections.
dosage:
Standard dose: 408 mg once daily.

Duration depends on condition — acne typically treated for 8–12 weeks.
sideEffects:
Nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhea, sun sensitivity.

Rare: allergic reactions, fungal infections.
importantInfo:
Take with a full glass of water.

Avoid milk, iron, or antacids near dosing time.

Use sun protection and avoid prolonged exposure.

name: Macrogol
description: Macrogol is a laxative used to treat constipation by retaining water in the bowel to soften stools and stimulate movement.
dosage:
1–3 sachets daily for constipation.

Higher doses (up to 8 sachets) for fecal impaction — under medical advice.
sideEffects:
Bloating, gas, stomach discomfort.

Rare: electrolyte imbalance with prolonged use.
importantInfo:
Dissolve powder in water before use.

Can be taken long term for chronic constipation.

Maintain good hydration while using.

name: Mebendazole
description: Mebendazole is an antiparasitic used to treat intestinal worm infections such as threadworm, roundworm, and whipworm.
dosage:
Single 100 mg dose for threadworm.

Repeat in 2–3 weeks if needed.

Other infections may require twice-daily dosing for 3 days.
sideEffects:
Abdominal pain, diarrhea, gas.

Rare: rash, allergic reactions, liver changes.
importantInfo:
Treat all household members for threadworm.

Maintain hygiene and wash bedding during treatment.

Avoid in pregnancy unless essential.

name: Mebeverine
description: Mebeverine is an antispasmodic used to relieve abdominal cramps, bloating, and discomfort associated with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
dosage:
135 mg tablets: one tablet three times daily before meals.

Modified-release capsules: 200 mg twice daily.
sideEffects:
Rare: allergic reactions (rash, itching, swelling).

Generally well tolerated.
importantInfo:
Do not crush or chew modified-release capsules.

Continue taking regularly for consistent relief.

Seek medical help for any signs of allergic reaction.

name: Medroxyprogesterone
brand: Provera, Depo-Provera, Sayana Press, Cycrin, Farlutal.
description: Medroxyprogesterone is a progestin hormone used for contraception, regulating menstrual cycles, or managing endometriosis and abnormal bleeding.
dosage:
Oral: 5–10 mg daily for 5–10 days per cycle.

Injection (Depo-Provera): 150 mg every 12 weeks.
sideEffects:
Weight gain, breast tenderness, mood changes, menstrual irregularities.

Long-term injection use: decreased bone density.
importantInfo:
May take time for periods to return after stopping.

Calcium and vitamin D intake important during use.

Report unusual bleeding or severe mood changes.

name: Melatonin
description: Melatonin is a hormone that regulates sleep-wake cycles. It is used to treat insomnia, jet lag, and delayed sleep phase disorder.
dosage:
2–5 mg 1–2 hours before bedtime.

Dose may vary depending on condition and age.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, vivid dreams, headache, nausea.

Rare: mood changes or confusion.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol or caffeine near bedtime.

Best taken at the same time each night.

Not recommended for long-term use unless advised.

name: Memantine
description: Memantine is used to treat moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It works by regulating glutamate to improve memory, attention, and behavior.
dosage:
Starting dose: 5 mg once daily, increased gradually to 20 mg/day.

Usually taken in divided doses.
sideEffects:
Dizziness, headache, confusion, constipation.

May cause hallucinations or agitation in some patients.
importantInfo:
Take with or without food.

Use caution in patients with seizures or kidney issues.

Report any sudden changes in mood or behavior.

name: Mesalazine
description: Mesalazine is an anti-inflammatory drug used to treat and prevent flare-ups of ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease by reducing inflammation in the colon.
dosage:
Typical oral dose: 2–4 g daily in divided doses.

Rectal formulations (suppositories/enemas) may be used for distal disease.
sideEffects:
Headache, nausea, abdominal pain, flatulence.

Rare: kidney issues, allergic rash, pancreatitis.
importantInfo:
Regular kidney function monitoring is advised.

Do not crush or chew modified-release tablets.

Inform your doctor if you develop new abdominal pain or rash.

name: Metformin
description: Metformin is a first-line medication for type 2 diabetes. It lowers blood sugar by reducing glucose production in the liver and improving insulin sensitivity.
dosage:
Initial: 500 mg once or twice daily with meals.

Maintenance: up to 2,000 mg/day in divided doses.
sideEffects:
Nausea, diarrhea, stomach upset.

Rare: lactic acidosis (serious).
importantInfo:
Take with food to reduce GI symptoms.

Do not use in severe kidney or liver disease.

Temporarily stop before major surgery or contrast imaging.

name: Methadone
description: Methadone is a long-acting opioid used to treat pain and as part of opioid substitution therapy for heroin or morphine addiction.
dosage:
Opioid dependence: 10–30 mg daily, titrated based on withdrawal symptoms.

Pain: 2.5–10 mg every 8–12 hours as needed.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, constipation, sweating, dry mouth.

Risk of dependence, respiratory depression, QT prolongation.
importantInfo:
Dose changes must be made cautiously — long half-life.

Avoid alcohol and sedatives.

ECG monitoring may be required for long-term use.

name: Methotrexate
description: Methotrexate is an immunosuppressant used to treat autoimmune conditions (like rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis) and certain cancers.
dosage:
Typically 7.5–25 mg once weekly (oral, subcutaneous, or IM).

Always taken once a week, not daily.
sideEffects:
Nausea, mouth ulcers, fatigue, low blood cell counts.

Serious: liver toxicity, lung issues, infection risk.
importantInfo:
Take folic acid to reduce side effects.

Regular blood tests required.

Do not take NSAIDs or alcohol without medical advice.

name: Methylphenidate
description: Methylphenidate is a stimulant used to treat ADHD and narcolepsy by increasing levels of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain.
dosage:
Immediate-release: 5–20 mg 2–3 times daily.

Modified-release: 18–72 mg once daily depending on brand and age.
sideEffects:
Loss of appetite, insomnia, increased heart rate, anxiety.

Rare: tics, mood changes, growth suppression in children.
importantInfo:
Take in the morning to avoid insomnia.

Monitor growth in children.

Avoid abrupt discontinuation without medical advice.

name: Metoclopramide
description: Metoclopramide is used to treat nausea, vomiting, and delayed stomach emptying. It increases stomach and intestinal movement.
dosage:
10 mg up to three times daily.

Short-term use (max 5 days) is recommended.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, restlessness, diarrhea.

Rare: movement disorders (especially in long-term use).
importantInfo:
Limit use to short term due to risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.

Avoid alcohol and sedatives.

Report any muscle stiffness or unusual movements.

name: Metoprolol
description: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker used to treat high blood pressure, angina, and heart rhythm disorders. It slows the heart rate and reduces blood pressure.
dosage:
Typical dose: 50–100 mg once or twice daily.

Extended-release forms available for once-daily dosing.
sideEffects:
Fatigue, dizziness, cold extremities, low heart rate.

May mask symptoms of low blood sugar in diabetics.
importantInfo:
Do not stop abruptly — taper off under supervision.

Take with food to improve absorption.

Monitor heart rate and blood pressure regularly.

name: Metronidazole
description: Metronidazole is an antibiotic and antiprotozoal used to treat bacterial vaginosis, pelvic infections, dental infections, and rosacea.
dosage:
Oral: 400–500 mg two to three times daily.

Topical and vaginal formulations used once or twice daily.
sideEffects:
Metallic taste, nausea, dizziness.

Rare: seizures, peripheral neuropathy.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol during and for 48 hours after use — may cause severe reaction.

Take with food if stomach upset occurs.

Complete the course even if symptoms improve.

name: Mirabegron
description: Mirabegron is used to treat overactive bladder symptoms like urgency, frequency, and urge incontinence. It relaxes the bladder muscle to increase storage capacity.
dosage:
Typical adult dose: 50 mg once daily.

Start with 25 mg if needed, especially in elderly or with renal impairment.
sideEffects:
Increased blood pressure, urinary tract infections, headache.

Rare: fast heart rate, allergic reactions.
importantInfo:
Check blood pressure regularly during treatment.

Do not crush or chew the tablets.

May take a few weeks to see full benefit.

name: Mirtazapine
description: Mirtazapine is an antidepressant used for depression, anxiety, and sleep disorders. It works by affecting serotonin and norepinephrine levels.
dosage:
Starting dose: 15 mg at bedtime.

Maintenance: 15–45 mg daily, usually taken at night due to sedative effects.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, increased appetite, weight gain, dry mouth.

May cause vivid dreams or dizziness.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol — may increase drowsiness.

Do not stop suddenly — taper under supervision.

May take 2–4 weeks to feel full benefit.

name: Molnupiravir (Lagevrio)
description: Molnupiravir is an antiviral used to treat mild to moderate COVID-19 in high-risk adults to reduce the risk of hospitalization.
dosage:
800 mg (four 200 mg capsules) every 12 hours for 5 days.

Should be started within 5 days of symptom onset.
sideEffects:
Diarrhea, nausea, dizziness.

Generally well tolerated in short courses.
importantInfo:
Not recommended in pregnancy.

Swallow capsules whole with water.

Complete the full course even if symptoms improve.

name: Mometasone
description: Mometasone is a corticosteroid used to treat asthma, allergic rhinitis, and inflammatory skin conditions. It reduces inflammation and itching.
dosage:
Nasal spray: 2 sprays per nostril once daily.

Inhaler: 220–440 mcg once or twice daily.

Topical: apply once daily to affected area.
sideEffects:
Dry nose or throat, sore throat, skin thinning (topical).

Rare: nosebleeds, headache.
importantInfo:
Rinse mouth after inhaler use to prevent thrush.

Do not use for longer than recommended without review.

Avoid eyes when using topical form.

name: Montelukast
description: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used to prevent asthma symptoms and treat seasonal allergies. It works by blocking inflammation-causing chemicals.
dosage:
Adults: 10 mg once daily in the evening.

Children: 4–5 mg once daily depending on age.
sideEffects:
Headache, abdominal pain, tiredness.

Rare: mood changes, sleep disturbances.
importantInfo:
Take at the same time each day.

Not a rescue medicine — do not use for sudden asthma attacks.

Discuss mood-related side effects with your doctor.

name: Morphine
brand: MST Continus, Sevredol, Oramorph, Zomorph, MXL.
description: Morphine is a strong opioid used to treat moderate to severe pain. It works by blocking pain signals in the brain and spinal cord.
dosage:
Immediate-release: 5–20 mg every 4 hours as needed.

Modified-release: 10–60 mg twice daily based on pain severity.
sideEffects:
Constipation, drowsiness, nausea, itching.

Serious: respiratory depression, dependence, confusion.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol and driving.

Use laxatives to prevent constipation.

Taper slowly if discontinuing after long-term use.

name: Naproxen
brand: Naprosyn, Aleve, Naprelan, Synflex, Feminax Ultra.
description: Naproxen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to relieve pain, inflammation, and stiffness in arthritis, period pain, and injury.
dosage:
Typical dose: 250–500 mg twice daily.

Maximum daily dose: 1,000 mg.
sideEffects:
Stomach pain, heartburn, dizziness.

Long-term: ulcers, kidney issues, cardiovascular risks.
importantInfo:
Take with food or milk to protect your stomach.

Avoid combining with other NSAIDs.

Inform your doctor if you have stomach or heart conditions.

name: Nefopam
description: Nefopam is a non-opioid painkiller used for moderate pain. It works by blocking pain signals in the brain but is not anti-inflammatory.
dosage:
Oral: 30–90 mg three times daily.

IV (hospital use): up to 20 mg every 4–6 hours.
sideEffects:
Nausea, dizziness, dry mouth, sweating.

May cause drowsiness or palpitations.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol and operating machinery.

Do not exceed recommended dose.

Not typically used long-term.

name: Nicorandil
brand: Ikorel, Angedil, Corodil, Nicoran, Nicorandil Accord.
description: Nicorandil is used to prevent chest pain (angina) by widening blood vessels and improving blood flow to the heart.
dosage:
Initial dose: 5–10 mg twice daily.

Maintenance: 10–20 mg twice daily depending on tolerance.
sideEffects:
Headache, flushing, dizziness.

Rare: mouth ulcers, low blood pressure.
importantInfo:
Do not stop suddenly without medical advice.

Avoid use with PDE5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil).

Report persistent ulcers or bleeding.

name: Nifedipine
description: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat high blood pressure and angina. It relaxes and widens blood vessels.
dosage:
Typical modified-release: 30–60 mg once daily.

Do not use immediate-release for long-term blood pressure control.
sideEffects:
Swollen ankles, headache, flushing, palpitations.

Rare: gum overgrowth.
importantInfo:
Do not chew or crush modified-release tablets.

Avoid grapefruit juice.

Monitor blood pressure regularly.

name: Nitrofurantoin
description: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic used to treat and prevent urinary tract infections. It works best in acidic urine environments.
dosage:
Treatment: 100 mg twice daily for 3–7 days.

Prevention: 50–100 mg once daily at night.
sideEffects:
Nausea, headache, urine discoloration (brown).

Rare: lung or liver problems with long-term use.
importantInfo:
Take with food or milk.

Stay hydrated and complete the course.

Do not use if you have kidney problems (low eGFR).

name: Nortriptyline
description: Nortriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant used to treat depression, nerve pain, and sometimes migraines or sleep disorders.
dosage:
Depression: 25–75 mg daily, typically at bedtime.

Nerve pain: lower doses (10–25 mg) initially.
sideEffects:
Drowsiness, dry mouth, constipation, weight gain.

Rare: heart rhythm issues, confusion in elderly.
importantInfo:
Do not stop suddenly.

Avoid alcohol and sedatives.

May take 2–4 weeks to see full benefit.

name: Nystatin
description: Nystatin is an antifungal medication used to treat infections caused by Candida, such as oral thrush, skin infections, and diaper rash.
dosage:
Oral suspension: 100,000 units four times daily, swish and swallow.

Topical: apply to affected area 2–3 times daily.
sideEffects:
Mild nausea, diarrhea (oral).

Topical: skin irritation or rash.
importantInfo:
Complete the full course even if symptoms improve.

Shake oral suspension well before use.

Do not use topical form on broken skin unless directed.

name: Oestrogen
brand: Premarin, Elleste Solo, Progynova, Estradot, Evorel.
description: Oestrogen is a hormone used in hormone replacement therapy (HRT) to treat menopausal symptoms and in contraception. It can be taken orally, topically, or as patches.
dosage:
Depends on formulation: oral (0.5–2 mg daily), patch (applied twice weekly), gel (daily).

Used continuously or cyclically.
sideEffects:
Breast tenderness, bloating, nausea, headache.

Increased risk of blood clots or stroke with long-term use.
importantInfo:
Use at the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration.

Report unusual bleeding, breast lumps, or leg swelling.

Combine with progesterone if uterus is intact (unless advised).

name: Olanzapine
description: Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and acute manic episodes.
dosage:
Starting dose: 5–10 mg once daily.

Maintenance: 10–20 mg daily depending on response.
sideEffects:
Weight gain, drowsiness, increased appetite, dry mouth.

Rare: high blood sugar, cholesterol changes, movement disorders.
importantInfo:
Monitor weight, blood sugar, and lipids.

Avoid alcohol.

May take several weeks for full effect.

name: Olmesartan
description: Olmesartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) used to treat high blood pressure by relaxing blood vessels.
dosage:
Typical starting dose: 10–20 mg once daily.

Maintenance: up to 40 mg daily.
sideEffects:
Dizziness, fatigue, back pain.

Rare: kidney issues, high potassium, severe diarrhea (sprue-like enteropathy).
importantInfo:
Monitor kidney function and potassium.

Avoid potassium supplements or NSAIDs unless advised.

Take at the same time daily.

name: Omeprazole
description: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) used to treat acid reflux, indigestion, stomach ulcers, and H. pylori infection. It reduces stomach acid production.
dosage:
Typical dose: 20–40 mg once daily.

May be taken twice daily for severe conditions or H. pylori treatment.
sideEffects:
Headache, abdominal pain, nausea, flatulence.

Long-term: low magnesium, B12 deficiency, fracture risk.
importantInfo:
Take 30–60 minutes before meals.

Do not crush or chew capsules.

Use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration.

name: Oxybutynin
description: Oxybutynin is used to treat overactive bladder and urinary incontinence by relaxing bladder muscles to reduce urgency and frequency.
dosage:
Immediate-release: 2.5–5 mg two or three times daily.

Extended-release: 5–10 mg once daily.

Patches and topical gels also available.
sideEffects:
Dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, drowsiness.

Rare: confusion, especially in elderly.
importantInfo:
Stay hydrated to manage dry mouth.

Avoid overheating — may reduce ability to sweat.

Use caution in glaucoma or older adults.

name: Oxycodone
description: Oxycodone is a strong opioid painkiller used for moderate to severe pain. It alters pain perception in the brain and spinal cord.
dosage:
Immediate-release: 5–20 mg every 4–6 hours as needed.

Modified-release: 10–80 mg twice daily, adjusted individually.
sideEffects:
Constipation, nausea, drowsiness, dizziness.

Serious: respiratory depression, dependence, low blood pressure.
importantInfo:
Avoid alcohol and sedatives.

Use laxatives to prevent constipation.

Do not crush or chew modified-release tablets.

name: Pantoprazole
description: Pantoprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) used to treat acid reflux, GERD, ulcers, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome by reducing stomach acid.
dosage:
20–40 mg once daily.

May be increased to 40 mg twice daily for severe conditions.
sideEffects:
Headache, diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain.

Long-term: magnesium or vitamin B12 deficiency.
importantInfo:
Take 30–60 minutes before meals.

Swallow tablets whole with water.

Regularly review need for long-term use.
